Common Themes And Application:
- The theme of praising and worshiping God is present in Psalm 98.
- The theme of God's presence and glory is highlighted in Ezekiel 10:1-19.
- The theme of the second coming of Jesus and the importance of being ready is emphasized in Luke 17:20-37.
- The life application from these passages is to continually praise and worship God, acknowledge His presence and glory in our lives, and be prepared for the return of Jesus.
Symbols1Summarize: The most important symbol in these verses that recurs throughout the Bible is the theme of salvation. It is mentioned in verse 1 when it says that God's right hand and holy arm have worked salvation, and again in verse 2 when it says that God has made his salvation known. This theme of salvation continues to develop throughout the Bible as it is mentioned in various contexts and fulfilled through Jesus Christ.
Symbols2Summarize: The most important symbol in these verses that recurs throughout the Bible is the presence of God's glory. It is depicted as a cloud and radiance that fills the temple, represented by the cherubim and the wheels. This symbol develops throughout the Bible as the glory of God is seen in various manifestations, such as the pillar of cloud and fire in the exodus from Egypt, the glory cloud in the Tabernacle, and the transfiguration of Jesus.
Symbols3Summarize: The most important symbol in these verses that recurs throughout the Bible is the coming of the Son of Man. In these verses, Jesus speaks about how people will long to see the Son of Man but won't find him easily. He also compares the coming of the Son of Man to the days of Noah and Lot, emphasizing the suddenness and unexpectedness of his arrival. This symbol of the coming of the Son of Man develops throughout the Bible, particularly in prophecies about the Messiah and Jesus' teachings about his eventual return.
Summarize1: Psalm 98 is a song of praise to the Lord for His salvation and righteousness. It calls for all the earth to shout for joy and make music to worship God, for He will come to judge the world with righteousness and equity.
Summarize2: In Ezekiel 10, the prophet sees a vision of God's glory departing from the temple. The cherubim and wheels are described in detail, and the glory of the Lord moves to the threshold of the temple, then to the entrance of the east gate of the Lord's house.
Summarize3: In Luke 17:20-37, Jesus responds to the Pharisees' question about when the kingdom of God will come. He explains that the kingdom of God is not something that can be observed externally, but rather it is within the believers. Jesus warns his disciples not to be misled by false claims of his return, emphasizing that when he does come, it will be sudden and like a flash of lightning. He compares his return to the days of Noah and Lot, stating that people were carrying on with their normal activities until sudden destruction came upon them. Jesus advises his followers to not be attached to their possessions and to remember Lot's wife, who turned back and was destroyed. He also states that when he returns, there will be a separation between those taken and those left behind. When asked where these events will occur, Jesus responds metaphorically, saying that wherever there is destruction and judgment, vultures will gather.
Behindinsights1: One interesting insight about this passage is that it emphasizes the universal nature of God's salvation. It mentions that God has revealed his righteousness to the nations and that all the ends of the earth have seen his salvation. This suggests that God's salvation is not limited to a specific group or region, but is available to all people.
Behindinsights3: One interesting insight about this passage is the comparison made by Jesus between the days of Noah and the days of the Son of Man. He parallels the obliviousness and indulgence of people in Noah's time, who were destroyed by the flood, with the state of the world when the Son of Man is revealed. It highlights the need for vigilance and readiness for the imminent coming of the Kingdom of God.
SocioSummary1: The psalm mentioned in the passage is attributed to David and is believed to have been written during the 10th century BCE, when the Israelites were establishing themselves as a nation in Canaan under King David's reign. The passage reflects a sense of triumph and celebration, praising God for salvation and righteousness. It suggests the Israelites may have been facing challenges or threats during this time, but does not provide specific socio-historical details of the surrounding geographies.
SocioSummary2: Ezekiel 10:1-19 was written during the Babylonian exile, when the Israelites were taken captive for their disobedience. It describes a vision of God's glory leaving the temple in Jerusalem, symbolizing the removal of divine protection and the abandonment of the temple. This reflects the desolation and destruction experienced by the Israelites during their exile.
SocioSummary3: During the events described in this passage, the region of Judea and Galilee was under Roman rule. The Jewish people, including the Pharisees, were living under Roman authority and subject to Roman laws and taxes. The region had a diverse religious landscape, with Judaism being the dominant faith but other religious groups and sects also present. There were also Greco-Roman influences and cultural norms in the area. Roman dominance and religious diversity characterized the socio-historical situation.

Scene1: This passage from Psalm 98 describes a scene of celebration and praise to the Lord, with people singing, playing music, and shouting for joy. It could be compared to a scene in the movie "Sister Act 2: Back in the Habit" where the choir performs a lively and energetic song, with the whole audience joining in and celebrating together.
Scene2: The scene from the movie that is similar to this passage is the climax of the movie "Raiders of the Lost Ark" when the Ark of the Covenant is opened. As the ark is opened, a cloud forms, and the power of God's glory is unleashed, causing destruction and devastation. Similarly, in Ezekiel 10, the glory of the Lord fills the temple, and the cherubim and wheels move in alignment with God's presence.
Scene3: The scene from the movie "Avengers: Infinity War" where Thor arrives on Wakanda and joins the battle against Thanos and his army is similar to this passage. In both instances, there is a sense of anticipation and waiting for a significant event to happen. In the movie, the arrival of Thor brings a powerful presence and turns the tide of the battle, just as Jesus describes the coming of the Son of Man as a dramatic and transformative event.

emily1:
Sing to the Lord a new song,
For wonders He has done.
His mighty hand, His holy arm,
By grace, salvation won.

His righteous ways, revealed to all,
To nations near and far.
His love, His faithfulness resound
In Israel's chosen star.

So shout for joy, all of the earth,
Let jubilant songs rise.
With harps and trumpets, let us sing,
Praise reaching to the skies.

Let sea and rivers join in praise,
Let mountains sing with glee.
For judgment day is drawing near,
In righteousness to see.

The Lord, in equity, will judge,
The world and all within.
So let this psalm remind us all,
Our lives, with love, begin.
emily2:
In the temple's sacred space,
The cherubim stood in grace,
A throne of lapis lazuli,
Overhead, a sight to see.

The glory of the Lord did rise,
From cherubim, to my surprise,
Through the clouds, the temple filled,
With radiance that thrilled and chilled.

The sound of wings, a voice divine,
Echoing through the hallowed shrine,
As the man clothed in linen stood,
Amidst the wheels, he understood.

Fire was taken from their midst,
Into his hands, the flames persist,
Scattering coals upon the city,
A vision of destruction, not pretty.

Four wheels ablaze with sparkling light,
Intersecting, shining, oh so bright,
Guided by the cherubim's gaze,
In any direction they would raze.

Eyes adorned each wing and hand,
These sacred beings, truly grand,
Four faces, cherub, human, lion, eagle,
Mystic creatures, divine and regal.

Then the cherubim took flight,
Ascending to celestial height,
Their wheels followed, never apart,
Moved by the spirit within their heart.

And alas, the glory took its leave,
No longer upon the temple's eave,
Departing, over the cherubim's place,
As they spread their wings and further grace.

At the east gate, they came to rest,
The God of Israel, they confessed,
And in this sacred tale we find,
A message for hearts and souls confined.

For is not the temple our own being?
Through which God's glory we are seeing,
Once filled with radiance, pure and bright,
Now dim with darkness, devoid of light.

Shall we scatter coals upon our way,
Embrace destruction day by day?
Or shall we rise, our wheels in tow,
Seek the divine, let our true selves grow?

Let us remember this holy sight,
The cherubim's flight, their radiant light,
For in their journey, we may divine,
A path to find God's glory within our shrine.
emily3:
The kingdom of God, so vast and grand,
Not confined to any specific land.
Not by observation, nor words we speak,
For the kingdom of God is in us, so deep.

Days of longing, as disciples we yearn,
Though the Son of Man we may not discern.
Beware false claims, the deceivers' call,
For the coming of Christ surpasses all.

As in Noah's time, they ate and drank,
Unaware of their impending fate, they sank.
And in Sodom, they went about their way,
Blind to destruction, they faced dismay.

When the Son of Man is fully revealed,
No time to go back and possessions shield.
Remember Lot's wife, do not look behind,
Lose your life to gain, don't be confined.

In one bed, two people may be found,
One taken, the other left on the ground.
Women grinding grain, side by side,
One taken, the other left denied.

"Where, Lord?" disciples' question in awe,
"Where will these events befall and draw?"
He answers, "Wherever the dead are seen,
Vultures will gather, where darkness convenes."

This scripture's lesson, to deeply explore,
The kingdom of God we seek and adore.
Within us, it resides, a blessed treasure,
May we embrace its presence and find true measure.
Snoop1:
Yo, check it, Snoop Dog's gonna drop a rhyme,
Lemme break it down, yo, one more time.
This here Psalm 98, gotta sing a new song,
'Cause the Lord's done wonders, been going strong.

His right hand and holy arm, that's where it's at,
Saving souls from the front to the back.
He made his salvation known to all,
Showed his righteousness, now hear the call.

He ain't forgettin' his love, his faithfulness to Israel,
All around the world, his name they can't conceal.
The ends of the earth, they all done seen,
Salvation from our God, know what I mean?

Shout it out, y'all, no need to be shy,
Get up and dance, let the music fly.
Grab the harp, let's make some noise,
Sing it loud like the girls and the boys.

Trumpets blaring, and horns that be blastin',
Shouting for joy, 'cause the King we're surpassin'.
The sea's resounding, the whole world rejoice,
Rivers clapping hands, let the mountains find their voice.

They all gotta sing praises before the Lord,
'Cause he's comin' to judge, nothin' to ignore.
He'll judge the world, keep it righteous and fair,
Equity for all, Snoop Dog's prayer.
Snoop2:
Yo, peep this, Snoop Dogg gonna break it down
Ezekiel 10, let's take a look around
A throne of lapis lazuli, shining bright
Over cherubim's heads, it's quite a sight

God told the man in linen, "Go in quick
Grab them burning coals, scatter 'em, be slick"
The cherubim stood on the temple's south side
Cloud filled the court, can't keep God's glory to hide

From above the cherubim, His glory did rise
Moved to the temple's threshold, oh so wise
The cloud filled the place, radiance everywhere
The wings of cherubim, their sound in the air

Man in linen grabbed fire, as God commanded
Standing beside a wheel, everything so candid
Cherubim reached out his hand, grabbed that fire
Passed it to the man, his mission to inspire

Those cherubim wheels, looking sparkly and bling
Like topaz they shone, doing their thing
Four wheels in a row, each lookin' the same
Like wheels runnin' within wheels, it's a whole new game

Cherubim moved, any direction they'd choose
No need to turn, never singin' the blues
They followed the head's lead, no need for u-turns
Movin' in sync, flyin' without any concerns

Eyes covered their bodies, wings and all
Those wheels were named "the whirling wheels," standing tall
Cherubim had four faces, each one so unique
Cherub, human, lion, and eagle, proud and sleek

Then those cherubim rose up high in the sky
Wheels moved with 'em, didn't leave 'em high and dry
When they stood still, wheels stood still too
Movin' together, spirit of life flowin' through

The glory of the Lord left, stopped above cherubim
And as I watched, cherubim's wings started to swim
They rose from the ground, wheels kickin' it at their side
Stopped at the east gate, God's glory they can't hide

That's Ezekiel 10, Snoop Dogg's breakin' it down
Cherubim, wheels, and God's glory all around
Knowin' that the divine spirit, it's always in play
So keep your eyes open, yo, each and every day
Snoop3:
Yo, Pharisees askin' when the kingdom of God droppin',
Jesus spittin' facts, sayin' it can't be seen, ain't no stoppin'.
It ain't a physical place you be lookin' for,
The kingdom of God is already up in your core.

Listen up, disciples, there's a time that'll come,
When you beg for the days of the Son of Man, but be left numb.
Folks gonna shout, "There he is!" or "Here he be!"
But don't be fooled, don't go chasin' after 'em, you see?

The Son of Man, when he come in his glory,
Gonna be like lightning, flashin' through the sky, tellin' his story.
But first, he gotta suffer, he gotta face rejection,
From this generation blind to his resurrection.

Just like in Noah's time, people livin' carefree,
Eatin', drinkin', marryin', no sign of worry.
But then the flood came, wiped 'em all away,
No time to escape, no place to stay.

Same thing happened in the days of Lot,
Eatin', drinkin', tradin', plantin', the whole plot.
But when Lot left Sodom, fire and sulfur rained,
Destroyed 'em all, nothin' was gained.

When the Son of Man revealed, it gon' go down,
No time to grab your stuff, keep your head in the crown.
Remember Lot's wife, don't look back in strife,
You tryna save your life, you end up losin' it, that's life.

On that night, two in a bed, only one gonna fly,
Two women grindin' grain, one gon' be left behind, oh my!
They askin' Jesus, "Where this gon' take place?"
He answer, "Where the vultures feast on a dead man's face."

So heed these words, my brothers and sisters, be aware,
The kingdom of God, it already here, everywhere.
Don't get caught up in the distractions of this worldly run,
Seek the kingdom within, and let God's light shine like the sun.
moviesummary1: Novels and movies that carry similar themes or storylines to the exultation and praise expressed in Psalm 98 include The Song of Achilles, Les Mis√©rables, The Lion King, The Lord of the Rings trilogy, and Chariots of Fire. These works explore themes of love, heroism, redemption, faith, justice, forgiveness, restoration, bravery, sacrifice, and the triumph of good over evil.
moviesummary2: The passage from Ezekiel 10:1-19 deals with the presence and movement of supernatural beings. While it's hard to find exact parallels in novels or movies, there are works like "American Gods" by Neil Gaiman, the "Harry Potter" series, "The Chronicles of Narnia" by C.S. Lewis, and the film "Pan's Labyrinth" that explore similar themes of divine encounters and the presence or absence of supernatural beings.
moviesummary3: Luke 17:20-37 is a passage in the Bible that also explores the theme of anticipation and unexpected arrival. In this passage, Jesus talks about the coming of the Kingdom of God and warns his disciples to be watchful and ready for its arrival, as it will come unexpectedly, just as the flood did in the time of Noah. Jesus teaches that people should not be preoccupied with worldly matters, but instead, be prepared for the coming of the Son of Man, who will judge the world and separate the righteous from the unrighteous.

Secularsong2: A secular song that expresses similar sentiments to the passage in Ezekiel 10:1-19 is "Losing My Religion" by R.E.M. It explores themes of losing faith and the departure of something sacred or significant.

Cristiansong2:
A Christian song that describes the sentiment or situation in the passage is "Holy Spirit Rain Down" by Hillsong Worship.

The lyrics of the song convey a similar sentiment of God's glory departing and His Spirit filling the atmosphere:

"Fall afresh on me
Melt me, mold me, fill me, use me
Spirit of the living God, fall afresh on me"

The song acknowledges the presence and power of the Holy Spirit, which parallels the departure of God's glory in Ezekiel's vision. It speaks of surrendering to the Spirit's movement and allowing Him to work in and through us.

The lyrics reflect the message of staying prepared and vigilant for the return of Jesus.

applicationq1: How can we respond to God's salvation and righteousness being revealed to the nations?
applicationq2: How does this passage illustrate the departure of God's glory from the temple, and what does it teach us about the importance of God's presence in our lives?
applicationq3: How should we respond to the anticipation of the coming of the Son of Man, knowing that the kingdom of God is already in our midst?
Enneagram1:
Type 2 (Helper) may find meaning in this passage by:
- Appreciating the Lord's salvation and love as a validation of their desire to help and serve others.
- Feeling inspired to spread joy and happiness by singing and making music.
- Believing in the importance of judging the world with fairness and equity.

Type 7 (Enthusiast) may interpret this passage by:
- Seeing the Lord's marvelous works as an invitation to explore and experience all the wonders of the world.
- Feeling energized by the call to shout for joy and make music in celebration.
- Being motivated to seek justice and equality, finding fulfillment in promoting a better and more harmonious world.
Enneagram2:
Type 1 (The Perfectionist) - May respond to this passage with a critical eye for any deviations from what they believe is right and just. They might focus on the symbolism of the wheels and cherubim as representations of divine order and hierarchy. They could engage in a thorough analysis of the text to understand God's message and the importance of following divine commands.

Type 4 (The Individualist) - May find themselves drawn to the mysticism and poetic language of the passage. They might be captivated by the vivid imagery of the cherubim, the wheels, and the glory of the Lord. They may see this as an expression of God's complexity and expectational beauty. They could delve into the emotional impact of the narrative and explore its symbolic significance.
Enneagram3:
Type 5: The Investigator

- The Investigator would approach this passage with a logical and analytical mindset.
- They would seek to understand the deeper meaning behind Jesus' words and the implications for the arrival of the kingdom of God.
- They might study different interpretations and compare them to historical and cultural contexts to gain a comprehensive understanding.
- The Investigator might also contemplate the metaphorical significance of the references to Noah, Lot, and the Son of Man to unravel the hidden messages within the passage.

Type 2: The Helper

- The Helper would read this passage with a compassionate and empathetic perspective.
- They might focus on Jesus' statement about the kingdom of God being in their midst and reflect on how they can contribute to its manifestation.
- The Helper would be sensitive to the suffering and rejection that Jesus mentions and contemplate ways to provide support and solace.
- They might also inquire about the fate of the people who will be taken or left behind, seeking to understand the implications of losing or preserving one's life.
Myersbriggs1:
- An extraverted personality (e.g. ESFP) might be energized and excited by the passage, as it encourages singing and making music to the Lord. They may want to gather a group of people to sing and play instruments together as an expression of joy and celebration.
- An introverted personality (e.g. INFP) might appreciate the introspection and reflection provoked by the passage. They may find solace and comfort in the idea of a loving God who works salvation and offers judgment with righteousness and equity.
Myersbriggs2:
- An ENFP might be captivated by the vivid descriptions of the cherubim, the wheels, and the glory of the Lord, finding the passage enchanting and full of symbolism.
- An ISTJ might focus more on the details and logistics described in the passage, such as the movements of the cherubim and the coordination between the wheels and the creatures, analyzing it from a practical perspective.
Myersbriggs3:
- An INFP might find deep spiritual meaning in this passage, focusing on the idea that the kingdom of God is present within oneself and not something that can be observed externally. They may reflect on the need to resist the temptation of external distractions and instead seek a personal connection with the divine.
- A ESTJ might approach this passage from a practical standpoint, emphasizing the importance of being prepared and not getting caught up in worldly matters. They may focus on the need to prioritize one's responsibilities and make wise choices, drawing lessons from the examples of Noah and Lot to avoid being caught off guard.
psychology1: One theme from this text is the joy and celebration in praising and worshiping God. Contemporary psychology research has found that expressing gratitude and engaging in religious or spiritual practices can have positive effects on mental health and well-being. Studies have shown that individuals who engage in religious practices such as prayer or attending religious services tend to experience lower levels of stress, depression, and anxiety (e.g., Koenig, McCullough, & Larson, 2001; Smith et al., 2003).
psychology2: One theme from this text is the departure of God's glory from the temple. Contemporary psychology research has found that spirituality and religious experiences can have significant effects on mental health and well-being. Studies have shown that individuals who have a strong sense of spirituality or engage in religious practices often experience greater levels of happiness, lower levels of stress, and have improved overall mental health. These findings highlight the importance of spirituality in psychological well-being. (Research sources needed for citation)
psychology3: One theme in this text is the idea that the kingdom of God is not something that can be observed or pinpointed in a specific location. Similarly, contemporary psychology research has found that happiness, fulfillment, and well-being are not solely dependent on external circumstances or material possessions. Instead, they are often found within individuals and can be cultivated through personal growth, positive relationships, and a sense of purpose (Lyubomirsky et al., 2005; Ryan & Deci, 2001).
biology1:
Theme: Praise and worship

Scientific Finding: Research has shown that singing and engaging in music can have positive effects on human health and well-being. Studies have found that singing can reduce stress, enhance mood, and improve immune function. Additionally, music therapy has been used to help individuals with neurological disorders regain speech and motor skills. 

Sources:
1. Fancourt, D., & Finn, S. (2019). What is the evidence on the role of the arts in improving health and well-being? A scoping review. World Health Organization.
2. Schlaug, G., Norton, A., Overy, K., & Winner, E. (2005). Effects of music training on the child's brain and cognitive development. Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences, 1060(1), 219-230.
biology2:
Theme: The movement and coordination of living creatures

Scientific Finding: The ability of bacteria to move in response to environmental stimuli is critical for their survival and colonization. Bacterial motility is enabled by specialized appendages called flagella, which rotate and propel the bacteria through their surroundings. Research has shown that bacteria can adjust the direction of their movement by modulating the rotation of their flagella based on chemical signals or changes in their environment. This coordination of movement allows bacteria to locate nutrients, avoid harmful substances, and navigate towards favorable conditions (Blair et al., 2008).

Reference:
Blair, D. F., Berg, H. C., & Berg, H. C. (2008). The Motility of Escherichia coli Cells in Viscoelastic Media. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 105(51), 19683--19688. https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.0806904105
biology3:
Theme: The unexpected and sudden nature of a scientific finding.

Scientific Finding: Researchers discovered that certain species of bacteria possess the ability to transfer antibiotic resistance genes to completely unrelated bacterial species through a process called horizontal gene transfer. This finding was unexpected and surprising, as it challenges the traditional understanding of how antibiotic resistance spreads. 

Research sources:
- Aminov, R. (2011). Horizontal gene exchange in environmental bacteria. Frontiers in microbiology, 2, 158.
- Smillie, C. S., Smith, M. B., Friedman, J., Cordero, O. X., David, L. A., & Alm, E. J. (2011). Ecology drives a global network of gene exchange connecting the human microbiome. Nature, 480(7376), 241-244.

Haiku 3: Kingdom unfolds near, Sudden as lightning's bright flash, Watch, remain aware.
